author: By Heather Murphy
title: Pandemic Bakers Are Going Pro
description: Once again, a period of turmoil has generated a new wave of professional bakers.
content: Before the pandemic, Max Kumangai spent his Saturdays singing and dancing his way through back-to-back performances of “Jagged Little Pill,” a rock musical on Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Baseball’s Sticky Situation
description: Doctoring baseballs with ultra-tacky substances has pitchers dominating and some questioning the game’s integrity. Can cleaning up the balls liven up the sport?
content: Since the season began in April, Major League Baseball’s umpires and league officials have been collecting baseballs by the thousands. Balls from games are inspected, with the most suspicious specimens being sent to an independent laboratory for analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: A High School Senior Won a $40,000 Scholarship. Then She Gave It Up.
description: Verda Tetteh, 17, was awarded the scholarship during the graduation ceremony at her Massachusetts high school. Moments later, she returned it and said it should go to a student who needed it more.
content: For weeks, Verda Tetteh felt qualms about applying for the $40,000 merit scholarship her high school in Fitchburg, Mass., offered graduating students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: Westminster Dog Show Photos: Who Wants to Go Outside?
description: After decades at Madison Square Garden, the dog show moves to the Lyndhurst riverside estate. And hundreds of dogs probably couldn’t be happier.
content: Don’t blame the dogs if they look a little confused: The Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show looks a lot different this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Bitcoin and Encryption: A Race Between Criminals and the F.B.I.
description: The F.B.I. scored two major victories, recovering a Bitcoin ransom and tricking lawbreakers with an encryption app. But criminals may still have the upper hand.
content: Whether it was gangsters a century ago speeding off in faster getaway cars, or terrorists and hackers in recent decades who shielded their communications through encrypted apps, criminals have perennially exploited technology to stay a step ahead of law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Joe Manchin Can Fix the Filibuster
description: In mending rather than ending the rule, he might get us a little closer to a workable middle ground.
content: It’s easy to sympathize with the liberal desire to bury the Senate filibuster forever. The 60-vote threshold for Senate legislation is a choke point in a political system defined by gridlock, sclerosis and futility. It provides an excuse for policy abdication, encouraging the legislative branch to cede authority to the presidency and the courts, and the Republican Party to decline to have a policy agenda at all. Its history is checkered, its pervasive use is a novelty of polarization, and its eventual disappearance seems inevitable — so why not adapt now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Steven Erlanger
title: Angela Merkel, Anchor of European Stability, Stays Focused at Her Final G7
description: The German chancellor, known for her commitment to compromise, is eager to revive deal-making on multilateral policy, joining the world’s top democratic leaders one last time. Can she be replaced?
content: BERLIN — When Angela Merkel hosted world leaders at a beach resort on Germany’s Baltic Sea Coast in 2007, she was barely into her first term as chancellor, a relative neophyte in global affairs whose vivid green jacket among eight men in dark suits emphasized her status as the only woman in the club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Andrew Das
title: Venezuela faces a coronavirus outbreak a day before the start of the Copa América.
description: At least a dozen Venezuela players and staff members tested positive, raising new doubts about the decision to hold the tournament in Brazil.
content: At least a dozen Venezuela players and staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus a day before they were to play Brazil in the opening match of the South American soccer championship, according to the health authorities in Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: F.D.A. Still Lacks a Permanent Chief, Despite Pressing, Weighty Problems
description: With the pandemic easing, the federal agency’s long-term agenda for drug approvals or new issues is languishing without a permanent commissioner.
content: The contested decision by the Food and Drug Administration earlier this week to approve a drug to treat Alzheimer’s has renewed concerns about the Biden administration’s prolonged delay in choosing a permanent commissioner to lead the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: In Myanmar, Health Care’s Collapse Takes Its Own Toll
description: Since the February coup, many physicians have refused to work at state-run hospitals. “I will never blame the doctors,” said a patient whose treatment stopped.
content: U Hla Min, a rice farmer in central Myanmar, was getting regular radiation therapy for cancer when the military seized power on Feb. 1. Initially expected to survive, he lasted less than three months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 2 million people board U.S. flights for the first time since the pandemic started.
description: Friday was the first time more than two million people boarded flights. Air travel was still below prepandemic levels.
content: More than two million travelers passed through U.S. airport security checkpoints on Friday, the first time since March 2020 that such a milestone had been reached, according to the Transportation Security Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: This Is the Summer the Youth Own New York
description: For decades, certain corners of the city were so smoothed by money they seemed off-limits to those just starting out as adults. But for one brief shining moment, it all belongs to the young.
content: Walking around Lower Manhattan on a recent weeknight, a middle-aged, slightly graying man wasn’t sure if it was he who had changed or New York. True, he hadn’t been out much lately … but something was different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Flushing taps, washing hands: Experts have advice for reopening offices safely.
description: As offices across the United States prepare to reopen, the risk of contracting the coronavirus has fallen significantly, especially for those who are fully vaccinated, though it has not disappeared entirely.
content: As offices across the United States prepare to reopen, the risk of contracting the coronavirus has fallen significantly, especially for those who are fully vaccinated, though it has not disappeared entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia scrambles to contain a new surge, as most of its people appear to be avoiding the Sputnik vaccine.
description: Moscow’s mayor said the city’s situation had “sharply worsened” in the past week.
content: MOSCOW — Russian officials scrambled on Saturday to slow the spread of a new wave of the coronavirus, ordering workers in Moscow to take next week off and pleading with the populace to make use of widely available vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Off-Duty Flight Attendant Is Detained After an In-Flight Struggle, Delta Says
description: Video from the flight showed a violent confrontation involving several people wrestling a man to the floor as someone said: “Get him down. Keep him down.”
content: An off-duty flight attendant took control of the public address system and then fought with passengers and crew members on board a Delta Air Lines flight on Friday in the latest outburst of violent behavior by airline passengers, the airline said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Yair Lapid Won’t Be Israel’s Next Leader. But He’s the Power Behind the Throne.
description: If a new coalition government wins a confidence vote in Parliament on Sunday, Naftali Bennett will be Israel’s next prime minister. He wouldn’t be there without Yair Lapid.
content: JERUSALEM — When Yair Lapid was a rising newspaper columnist in the late 1990s, his editor, Ron Maiberg, found him a pleasant but self-centered and often intransigent man who regularly failed to cede ground in an argument.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Mark Landler
title: Biden Tries to Rally G7 Nations to Counter China’s Influence
description: The president urged the leaders of wealthy democracies to offer hundreds of billions in loans to developing nations in a direct challenge to Beijing’s Belt-and-Road Initiative.
content: PLYMOUTH, England — President Biden urged European nations and Japan on Saturday to counter China’s growing economic and security influence by offering developing nations hundreds of billions in financing as an alternative to relying on Beijing for new roads, railways, ports and communications networks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Milton Moses Ginsberg, Unconventional Filmmaker, Dies at 85
description: His movies about a psychiatrist’s disintegration and a werewolf in the White House originally bombed, but they both drew favorable attention many years later.
content: Milton Moses Ginsberg, who directed two notably ambitious and eccentric films before falling into obscurity, one about the meltdown of a psychiatrist and the other about a press aide in a Nixon-like administration who becomes a murderous werewolf, died on May 23 in his apartment in Manhattan. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wolgelenter
title: Authorities limit the hajj to 60,000 pilgrims in Saudi Arabia, and other news from around the world.
description: The annual Muslim pilgrimage is scheduled to begin in mid-July, and attendees must be vaccinated and between 18 and 65 years old, the Saudi Press Agency said.
content: The annual hajj pilgrimage to Mecca next month will be restricted to 60,000 and limited to people living in Saudi Arabia because of the coronavirus pandemic, the Saudi Press Agency said on Saturday, as the authorities maintain tight restrictions on an event that usually draws millions of people from around the world every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: The House lifts its mask mandate for fully vaccinated individuals.
description: House officials distributed new guidelines issued by the attending physician of Congress, which preserves mask requirements for the unvaccinated.
content: Fully vaccinated lawmakers and staff members in the House of Representatives will no longer be required to wear a mask or maintain six feet of social distance, following updated guidance issued on Friday by Dr. Brian P. Monahan, the attending physician of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Nieh
title: A White-Knuckle Ride to the Dark Side of Love and Infidelity
description: In P.J. Vernon’s new thriller, “Bath Haus,” the protagonist’s decision to cheat on his partner spirals into nerve-racking terror.
content: BATH HAUS By P. J. Vernon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: In China’s latest outbreak, doctors say the infected get sicker, faster.
description: Four-fifths of symptomatic cases develop fevers, more than in earlier outbreaks. The findings match trends in other countries where the Delta variant is spreading.
content: As the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads in southeastern China, doctors say they are finding that the symptoms are different and more dangerous than those they saw when the initial version of the virus started spreading in late 2019 in the central city of Wuhan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: French Political Leader Pelted With Flour During Protest
description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the leader of the far-left party France Unbowed, was showered with flour in Paris, just days after President Emmanuel Macron was slapped in the face.
content: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, a far-left political leader in France and a likely high-profile candidate in next year’s presidential election, was pelted with flour at a protest on Saturday, days after President Emmanuel Macron was slapped in the face as he sought to shake hands with voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Garland Confronts Long-Building Crisis Over Leak Inquiries and Journalism
description: Prosecutors’ approach to unauthorized disclosures of government secrets has undergone a sea change in the 21st century.
content: WASHINGTON — Government leak hunters have been ratcheting up pressure on the ability of journalists to do their jobs for a generation — a push fueled by changing technology and fraught national-security issues that arose after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Now, those tensions have reached an inflection point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Has New York Hit a Progressive Plateau? The Mayor’s Race Is a Key Test.
description: Concerns about crime are dominating the Democratic primary, and the party’s left wing has just started to coalesce.
content: A year ago, the left wing of New York’s Democratic Party was ascendant. Deeply progressive candidates triumphed in state legislative primaries and won a congressional upset, activists fueled a movement to rein in the power of the police, and Mayor Bill de Blasio agreed to cut the Police Department budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: An Unlikely Champion Wins the French Open, and Thanks a Mentor
description: Barbora Krejcikova developed her multifaceted game with the help of the former Wimbledon champion Jana Novotna, who died in 2017.
content: PARIS — Hand pointing to the sky, the new French Open champion Barbora Krejcikova gave credit where she knew it was due on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Born on the Left, Data for Progress Comes of Age in Biden’s Washington
description: A liberal think tank has grown comfortable with mainstream influence. Other activists say that being “normie” means it’s selling out.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Fat Cats on a Hot Tin Roof
description: Pay up, Monopoly Men; freeloading isn't cool.
content: WASHINGTON — I find this all quite taxing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Shashank Bengali
title: A thrilling tennis match won fans an exception to France’s curfew.
description: French officials delivered one of the great moments of sports in the pandemic on Friday night, as the clock crept toward an 11 p.m. curfew in Paris that seemed destined to clear the stands during an epic French Open men’s tennis semifinal between Rafael Nadal of Spain and Novak Djokovic of Serbia.
content: French officials delivered one of the great moments of sports in the pandemic on Friday night, as the clock crept toward an 11 p.m. curfew in Paris that seemed destined to clear the stands during an epic French Open men’s tennis semifinal between Rafael Nadal of Spain and Novak Djokovic of Serbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Saporito
title: Why AT&T Is Retreating From Its ‘Synergy’ Gamble
description: In acquiring WarnerMedia, it believed  pairing distribution with content was the key to the future. Apparently not.
content: Hold the phone. Or at least, hold on to the phone. Sell everything else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: One Woman’s Journey Through Chinese Atrocities
description: If we say Xi Jinping is committing genocide, can we do nothing?
content: In 2021 the United States and other countries have declared that China is committing genocide against ethnic Uyghurs — yet nothing much changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Lilith, Lilibet … Lucifer? How Baby Names Went to ‘L’
description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are hardly the only new parents gravitating toward quirk, family tradition and “L” names.
content: Give Prince Harry and Meghan Markle credit: The monarchs of Montecito, Calif., managed to come up with a name — Lilibet — for their new baby daughter that is so distinctive that it is all but unheard-of outside of Buckingham Palace or “The Crown.” (For the uninitiated, Lilibet is a royal family nickname for the prince’s grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, derived from her mispronunciation of her own name when she was a child.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Davidoff Solomon
title: In Defense of SPACs
description: These complex takeover vehicles serve an important purpose that’s worth protecting.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: The G7 leaders get down to business, taking on climate change and the pandemic.
description: The Group of 7 leaders reach the heart of their annual summit meeting on Saturday, with the pandemic, climate change, China and Russia likely to be on the agenda at their gathering in Cornwall, England.
content: The Group of 7 leaders reach the heart of their annual summit meeting on Saturday, with the pandemic, climate change, China and Russia likely to be on the agenda at their gathering in Cornwall, England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: One Way Forward on Iran: A Nuclear-Weapons-Free Persian Gulf
description: Regional rivalries lie at the heart of opposition to the nuclear pact. Could a revived agreement chart a better path?
content: An agreement to revive the nuclear deal with Iran appears possible as the United States and its partners are set to convene next week in Vienna for the sixth round of talks with Iranian diplomats since April. That’s welcome news, as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, the deal’s full name, imposed important restrictions on Iran’s nuclear program in exchange for a lifting of sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: In Making the French Open Final, Djokovic Edges Closer to His Rivals
description: Novak Djokovic defeated Rafael Nadal in four fierce sets and will try to win his 19th Grand Slam title against Stefanos Tsitsipas on Sunday.
content: PARIS — This golden age of men’s tennis got a little shinier on Friday night. It is harder to deepen the impression at this advanced stage: after all the comebacks, marathon duels and winners under pressure over nearly 20 years of close character study. But Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal, in their 58th meeting, still found something inside themselves that spoke to their public, which was allowed the privilege of staying in their seats past the 11 p.m. curfew by the French authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden will hold a solo news conference rather than pairing with Putin after their summit.
description: After President Biden meets his Russian counterpart on Wednesday, the two men will not face the news media at a joint news conference, United States officials said on Saturday.
content: After President Biden meets his Russian counterpart on Wednesday, the two men will not face the news media at a joint news conference, United States officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Maple Leaf
description: Come get some northern exposure in Stephen McCarthy’s New York Times puzzle debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I am in awe of bucket list puzzles like this one — elaborate (and often debut) grids where it all comes together, and I feel a little sorry for everyone who doesn’t see its title and the biographical information that runs in print. Stephen McCarthy is a new constructor — this is his first published puzzle anywhere — who hails from Vancouver Island, British Columbia. He’s a Ph.D. student in Stockholm, Sweden, studying transportation modeling, playing Ultimate Frisbee and singing in Stockholm’s Gay Choir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Barbora Krejcikova Wins the French Open
description: Unseeded but the sentimental favorite, Krejcikova defeated Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, to win the women’s singles title in Paris.
content: PARIS — Barbora Krejcikova won the French Open Saturday, beating Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova in three sets, 6-1, 2-6, 6-4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At the French Open Grounds, a Guided Tour of Change
description: A tennis writer has watched Roland Garros evolve and grow for 30 years, for better or worse.
content: PARIS — In my 30th year of covering the French Open, I am in need of a map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: In a Crisis, India’s Modi Could Always Change the Narrative. Then Came Covid.
description: His efforts to squelch dissent and to accentuate the positive may not be able to counter widespread anger over his government’s stumbling response, undermining a key part of his strategy for wielding power.
content: NEW DELHI — As India gasped for air at the peak of its Covid devastation, its leader appeared to advise his people to just breathe normally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jacob deGrom Stays Calm After Leaving Start With Elbow Pain
description: The Mets ace allowed just one hit in six innings before exiting. “My level of concern is not too high,” deGrom said.
content: Jacob deGrom did it all Friday night, pitching and hitting the Mets to victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aubree Nichols
title: Breaking Her Way Out of the ‘Shecession’
description: The pandemic has caused huge job losses among women. A program called Selfmade aims to help by teaching entrepreneurial skills.
content: When Jackie Grandchamps, 40, a marketing manager in Brooklyn, was furloughed by American Express Global Business Travel in April of last year, she collected unemployment and thought about reviving her passion project, a small-batch skin care line called Cecile’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can I Make My Neighbor Mow His Lawn?
description: City rules require homeowners to keep up their spaces. But sometimes your neighbor may need a little help.
content: Q: I live in a single-family house in Queens. My next-door neighbor mows his lawn once, maybe twice a year. The grass is already knee high, and I’m dreading the summer. I’m also worried that the high grass could attract vermin and other pests. What can I do to make him mow?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Extreme, Widespread Drought in the West, and the Hottest Months Are Still to Come
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 12, 2021.
content: “There’s a 100 percent chance that it gets worse before it gets better.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Picnic Sides Galore
description: Saturdays are for esquites, panzanella and macaroni salad.
content: Heading to a picnic today and need to bring a side? Pack up Millie Peartree’s macaroni salad, Kay Chun’s esquites (above) or Gabrielle E.W. Carter’s country panzanella with watermelon dressing — you can’t go wrong. Then tomorrow, when you’re gearing up for the week ahead, make Eric Kim’s Ritzy Cheddar chicken breasts, a perfect Sunday supper when paired with a big green salad. There’s more where that came from in our weekly collection of the most popular recipes on New York Times Cooking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl
title: President Biden and Jill Biden will meet with the queen at Windsor Castle.
description: The royal family’s presence around the Group of 7 summit meeting is unusually strong this year.
content: President Biden and his wife, Jill Biden, are scheduled to meet again with Queen Elizabeth II on Sunday at Windsor Castle as part of the U.S. leader’s first foreign trip as president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Richard Silvestri challenges our summer brains.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — There are some really tough entries in this cryptic — many of which come with difficult multistep clues — so if you got stuck on a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside an enigma, know that I did, too. Several times. Mostly in the northeast and southwest corners, which required multiple breaks and multidirectional attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker and Danny Hakim
title: Private Inequity: How a Powerful Industry Conquered the Tax System
description: The I.R.S. almost never audits private equity firms, even as whistle-blowers have filed claims alleging illegal tax avoidance.
content: There were two weeks left in the Trump administration when the Treasury Department handed down a set of rules governing an obscure corner of the tax code.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada rejects 300,000 doses of the J.&J. vaccine made in the U.S. because of contamination issues.
description: The Canadian regulator also banned the use of all products made at Emergent BioSolutions’ plant in Baltimore until it conducts an on-site inspection.
content: Canada’s health products regulator has rejected the country’s first and only shipment of Johnson & Johnson’s Covid vaccine because of contamination issues at the U.S. plant that produced it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Covid-Sniffing Dogs Are Accurate but Face Hurdles for Widespread Use
description: Logistics, cost and official standards are needed for the dogs to fulfill their potential in medical fields.
content: Dog noses are great Covid-19 detectors, according to numerous laboratory studies, and Covid sniffing dogs have already started working in airports in other countries and at a few events in the United States, like a Miami Heat basketball game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: U.F.C. 263: Adesanya and Vettori Get Their Rematch
description: Adesanya, one of the U.F.C.’s most marketable stars, makes his first appearance since trying to win a championship in a heavier weight class.
content: PHOENIX — A shirtless, chiseled Israel Adesanya held the gold Ultimate Fighting Championship middleweight belt above his head as his opponent, Marvin Vettori, sneered and hurled vulgarities at the champion during a news conference. U.F.C. President Dana White separated them with his outstretched arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What Weird Games Lurk on Your Kid’s Tablet?
description: Huge Kid Cesarean Birth in Hospital? Toddler Foot Doctor?
content: On Monday, Sara Schaefer was hanging out in her brother’s living room in Midlothian, Va., with her 5-year-old niece, who was playing a game on her tablet. Two days earlier, the kid had put $900 worth of toys and princess-related detritus in the family’s Amazon shopping cart, though she was unsuccessful in purchasing her haul. So her tablet use was getting a little extra scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Erin Griffith
title: What Is a Flying Car?
description: Inside Silicon Valley’s 10-year quest to make soaring above a crowded city street as easy as calling an Uber.
content: It was sleek, cone-shaped, a little confusing — like something Hollywood would give a sci-fi villain for a quick getaway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Denmark’s Christian Eriksen collapsed on the field. He is responsive and awake.
description: The midfielder was walking near the sideline when he fell over. Medical teams offered urgent treatment on the field.
content: Denmark midfielder Christian Eriksen collapsed to the field late in the first half of his team’s game against Finland at Euro 2020 on Saturday, a frightening moment that played out before a stadium filled with fans and broadcast to a live global television audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Humpback Whale Nearly Eats a Lobsterman, Then Thinks Better of It
description: Michael Packard, a lobster diver in Provincetown, Mass., found himself inside the mouth of a whale on Friday morning, then was spit out.
content: It was sunny and clear on Friday morning and the water was calm off the coast of Provincetown, Mass., where Michael Packard was diving for lobsters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: 14 People Are Injured in Shooting in Downtown Austin, Police Say
description: The interim police chief said that the shooting appeared to have started as “some kind of disturbance between two parties” and that most of the victims were “innocent bystanders.”
content: A shooting in a popular nightlife district in downtown Austin, Texas, early on Saturday left 14 people injured, with two of them in critical condition, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Oyster Farmers Who Feared Going Broke Brace for a ‘Bonkers’ Summer
description: When restaurants closed to slow the spread of the coronavirus, the nationwide market for oysters cratered. That’s not the end of the story.
content: A year ago, oyster growers who farm New Jersey’s marshy coastal inlets and tidal flats were fighting for survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Elizabeth Dias
title: ‘Take the Ship’: Conservatives Aim to Commandeer Southern Baptists
description: The insurgents, some adopting a pirate motif, believe that the denomination has drifted too far to the left on issues of race, gender and the strict authority of the Bible.
content: Allen Nelson IV walked to the front of his small church in central Arkansas, stopped in front of the communion table with three large crosses behind him, and unfurled a giant black flag with a white skull and crossed swords.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Donald Trump Is Starving
description: A glutton for attention is yanked away from the buffet.
content: Frank Bruni will stop writing regular Opinion columns in late June, but his popular weekly newsletter will live on. To keep up with his political analysis, cultural commentary and personal reflections, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Mudcat Grant, American League’s First Black 20-Game Winner, Dies at 85
description: After 14 major league seasons, he wrote a book about Black pitchers and sang in nightclubs. “I made way more money in music than I did in baseball,” he said.
content: Mudcat Grant, who helped take the Minnesota Twins to the 1965 World Series when he became the American League’s first Black pitcher to post a 20-win season, has died at 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Climate Protesters Rally on the Streets and at Sea Amid G7 Summit
description: Groups of demonstrators gathered in Falmouth, England, on Saturday to protest the effects of climate change as world leaders met for the G7 summit.
content: Groups of demonstrators gathered in Falmouth, England, on Saturday to protest the effects of climate change as world leaders met for the G7 summit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Oregon Lawmakers Expel Representative Over Capitol Breach
description: Lawmakers in Oregon voted, 59 to 1, to expel a colleague, Rep. Mike Nearman, from office on Thursday for his role in helping a crowd breach the State Capitol in December, the first time in history that an Oregon legislator was expelled.
content: Lawmakers in Oregon voted, 59 to 1, to expel a colleague, Rep. Mike Nearman, from office on Thursday for his role in helping a crowd breach the State Capitol in December, the first time in history that an Oregon legislator was expelled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Macron Says U.S. Is ‘Definitely’ Back, as Biden Repairs Ties With Europe
description: While posing for photos with President Biden at the G7 meeting in England on Saturday, President Emmanuel Macron of France confidently told reporters that he agreed with Mr. Biden that the United States was back as a global ally.
content: While posing for photos with President Biden at the G7 meeting in England on Saturday, President Emmanuel Macron of France confidently told reporters that he agreed with Mr. Biden that the United States was back as a global ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: At Least 14 People Hurt in Austin Shooting
description: The police said a shooting near a crowded area in downtown Austin, Texas, early on Saturday left at least 14 people wounded or injured, with two in critical condition. It was unclear how many people opened fire and what led to the shooting.
content: The police said a shooting near a crowded area in downtown Austin, Texas, early on Saturday left at least 14 people wounded or injured, with two in critical condition. It was unclear how many people opened fire and what led to the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tom Hanks and the History We Need to Learn
description: Reacting to an essay by Mr. Hanks, readers discuss the Tulsa race massacre and other parts of our history, both shameful and inspiring, that are often not taught.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 12, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 12, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about a photo project for The Times Magazine misstated the relationship between a woman and the relative she was meeting for the first time when she was photographed. It was her great-grandchild, not her grandchild.
source.name: The New York Times
